SQL Queries

Query the semantic layer with familiar SQL syntax.

What This Is For

The SQL interface lets you query pre-defined metrics and dimensions using familiar SQL syntax. You can filter, sort, and combine data across models - the semantic layer handles joins and aggregations automatically.

Good for: - Exploring metrics across dimensions (SELECT revenue, status FROM orders WHERE region = 'US') - Building dashboards and reports with consistent metric definitions - Querying across related models without writing joins - Using parameters for dynamic filters (WHERE date >= {{ start_date }})

Not for: - Ad-hoc analytics with SUM(), COUNT(), or other aggregation functions - Complex SQL operations like subqueries, CTEs, or window functions - One-off queries that don’t fit your metric definitions

If you need ad-hoc SQL: Use layer.compile() to generate base SQL, then modify and execute it yourself.

SQL Support Overview

Feature Supported Notes
SELECT ✅ Yes Metrics and dimensions
SELECT * ✅ Yes Expands to all model fields
WHERE ✅ Yes Standard SQL conditions
ORDER BY ✅ Yes Sort by any field
LIMIT / OFFSET ✅ Yes Pagination support
Parameters ✅ Yes { param } syntax
Cross-Model Queries ✅ Yes Auto-joins via relationships
JOIN ❌ No Joins are automatic
GROUP BY ❌ No Grouping is automatic
Aggregate Functions ❌ No Use pre-defined metrics
HAVING ❌ No Use WHERE on metrics instead
Subqueries ❌ No Not supported
CTEs / WITH ❌ No Not supported
Window Functions ❌ No Use cumulative metrics
DISTINCT ❌ No Dimensions are auto-distinct
UNION / INTERSECT ❌ No Set operations not supported
INSERT / UPDATE / DELETE ❌ No Read-only semantic layer

Basic Queries

layer.sql("SELECT revenue FROM orders")

layer.sql("""
    SELECT revenue, status
    FROM orders
    WHERE status = 'completed'
""")

Supported Features

SELECT

Select measures and dimensions:

SELECT revenue, order_count, status
FROM orders

Table prefixes optional (inferred from FROM):

-- Both work
SELECT orders.revenue FROM orders
SELECT revenue FROM orders

WHERE

Filter with standard SQL conditions:

SELECT revenue
FROM orders
WHERE status = 'completed'
  AND order_date >= '2024-01-01'
  AND amount > 100

ORDER BY

SELECT revenue, status
FROM orders
ORDER BY revenue DESC, status ASC

LIMIT / OFFSET

SELECT revenue FROM orders LIMIT 10

SELECT revenue FROM orders LIMIT 10 OFFSET 5

Cross-Model Queries

Reference multiple models - joins happen automatically:

SELECT
    orders.revenue,
    customers.region,
    regions.country
FROM orders

SELECT *

Expands to all dimensions and measures:

SELECT * FROM orders
-- Expands to all dimensions + measures in orders model

Parameters

Use { param } syntax:

layer.sql(
    """
    SELECT revenue
    FROM orders
    WHERE order_date >= {{ start_date }}
      AND region = {{ region }}
    """,
    parameters={
        "start_date": "2024-01-01",
        "region": "US"
    }
)
WarningDon’t Quote Parameters

Parameters are automatically quoted based on type: - ❌ WHERE date >= '{{ start_date }}' (creates ''2024-01-01'') - ✅ WHERE date >= {{ start_date }}

Limitations

These SQL features are NOT supported:

No Explicit JOINs

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT *
FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id

✅ Instead:

-- Just reference both models - joins happen automatically
SELECT orders.revenue, customers.name
FROM orders

No GROUP BY

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT status, SUM(amount)
FROM orders
GROUP BY status

✅ Instead:

-- Grouping is automatic based on dimensions
SELECT revenue, status
FROM orders

No Aggregate Functions

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT COUNT(*), SUM(amount)
FROM orders

✅ Instead, define measures:

metrics:
  - name: order_count
    agg: count
  - name: revenue
    agg: sum
    sql: amount

Then:

SELECT order_count, revenue FROM orders

No Subqueries

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT * FROM (
    SELECT revenue FROM orders
) AS subquery

No CTEs/WITH

❌ Can’t write:

WITH temp AS (SELECT * FROM orders)
SELECT * FROM temp

No HAVING

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT status, revenue
FROM orders
HAVING revenue > 1000

✅ Use WHERE on measures instead:

SELECT status, revenue
FROM orders
WHERE revenue > 1000  -- This works!

No Window Functions

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT revenue, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY status)
FROM orders

✅ Use table calculations or cumulative measures instead.

No DISTINCT

❌ Can’t write:

SELECT DISTINCT status FROM orders

✅ Just select the dimension:

SELECT status FROM orders

No UNION/INTERSECT/EXCEPT

❌ Set operations not supported.

No INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE

Read-only semantic layer.

Why These Limitations?

The semantic layer rewrites your SQL to use pre-defined measures and handle joins automatically. This means:

  1. Measures must be pre-defined - No ad-hoc SUM() in SELECT
  2. Joins are automatic - Based on model relationships
  3. Grouping is automatic - Based on dimensions selected

This trade-off ensures: - ✅ Consistent metric definitions - ✅ Automatic join handling - ✅ Symmetric aggregate deduplication - ✅ Centralized business logic

Best Practices

TipDefine Once, Query Anywhere

Define metrics in YAML:

metrics:
  - name: revenue
    agg: sum
    sql: amount

Then query with simple SQL:

SELECT revenue FROM orders
TipComplex Logic in Measures

Put complex logic in measure definitions, not queries:

# Define complex measure
metrics:
  - name: high_value_revenue
    agg: sum
    sql: "CASE WHEN amount > 1000 THEN amount ELSE 0 END"
-- Simple query
SELECT high_value_revenue FROM orders
WarningFilter on Joined Tables

Only filter on tables that are actually joined:

❌ This fails (customers not joined):

SELECT orders.revenue
WHERE customers.region = 'US'

✅ Include a dimension to force join:

SELECT orders.revenue, customers.region
WHERE customers.region = 'US'

Programmatic Alternative

For full flexibility, use the programmatic API:

result = layer.query(
    metrics=["orders.revenue"],
    dimensions=["orders.status"],
    filters=["orders.status = 'completed'"],
    order_by=["orders.revenue DESC"],
    limit=10
)

Or generate SQL and execute yourself:

sql = layer.compile(
    metrics=["orders.revenue"],
    dimensions=["orders.status"]
)

# Modify as needed
sql += " UNION SELECT ..."

# Execute directly
conn.execute(sql)
